articles.title: AUGUST 1985
articles.summary: This document outlines the schedule of events for August 1985, including several star parties at different state parks, general meetings, and a board meeting. Key events include a presentation on the New Guinea total solar eclipse by Ernest W. Piini, a telescope sale, and an 'Equipment and Slide Night', with a significant conference also scheduled for September 1985.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: This article details the author's frustrating Yosemite trip, marked by car troubles (blown head gasket in Turlock due to overheating) and significant organizational issues with the federal park service regarding a large astronomy group event. Despite advanced planning, the park seemed unprepared for the group's size and family attendance, leading to confusion over fees and campsite arrangements. However, the public stargazing event itself was a success, with an estimated 800 park guests enjoying observations through approximately 30 telescopes.

articles.title: The weather was excellent for observing.
articles.summary: The article recounts a successful astronomy observing event, likely held at Yosemite, characterized by excellent weather and clear, steady skies. Participants enjoyed high-magnification views of Jupiter, impressive clarity from a 3.5-inch refractor, and the efficient operation of a modified computerized telescope. Beyond stargazing, the event included scenic hikes, 'hero' photography on cliffs, and a lavish culinary spread provided by the San Jose Gastronomical Association, concluding as an enjoyable experience despite minor logistical issues.

articles.title: COE PARK STAR PARTY
articles.summary: Attendees of the Coe Park Star Party are reminded that the observing area is smaller than other sites, urging careful parking to avoid blocking roads and potential issues with Park Rangers. Additionally, due to extreme fire danger, participants must be mindful of parking locations to prevent catalytic converters from igniting dry grass, and smoking is strictly prohibited.

articles.title: SJAA 1955 - 1985 THIRTY YEARS AND COUNTING
articles.summary: This article commemorates the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) 30th anniversary (1955-1985), reflecting on its evolution and growth. It notes the decline in local observing conditions over three decades while celebrating the association's achievements, including a robust membership, significant contributions to amateur astronomy, the expansion of its 'Ephemeris' bulletin, and current projects like a potential permanent site at Grant Ranch Park.

articles.title: LOOKING AHEAD: A growing Bay Area will only mean over population and more light pollution. The increase in light pollution will also mean driving further and further to dark sky sites for astronomical observation. We'll probably see a return of homebuilt telescopes as commercially made units steadily rise in price. CB's are already nearing the $3000 mark. But the commercially available telescopes will probably become more and more computerized, as already in 1985 a major manufacturer has entered the automated telescope market. It's hard to predict what size telescopes SJAA members will be using in the 21st century, but 15 inch reflector scopes are common place, but the refractor is also finding its place once again in the amateur's hands.
articles.summary: This article looks ahead at the future of amateur astronomy, particularly in the growing Bay Area, predicting increased light pollution requiring longer drives to dark sky sites. It anticipates a return to homebuilt telescopes due to rising commercial prices, alongside a trend towards more computerized commercially available units. The piece also encourages greater participation among San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) members, citing Halley's Comet's return as a prime opportunity for engagement.

articles.title: SJAA 2015
articles.summary: The SJAA Video Magazine for this month features Kevin Medlock's 60-inch space telescope project and Robert Fingerput's experience viewing Jupiter from Earth orbit. Additionally, John Gleason of AstroPhoto Films Inc. offers advice on enhancing Comet Halley astrophotos with a home computer, and King Dibble hosts a star party.

articles.title: THE GREAT FPOA TELESCOPE SALE
articles.summary: The Fremont Peak Observatory Association (FPOA) is holding "THE GREAT FPOA TELESCOPE SALE" on August 10th. This event will offer over a hundred telescopes, some brand new, as well as equatorial mounts and tripods. All proceeds from the sale will benefit the 30" observatory project.

articles.title: MOON SHADOW EXPEDITION TO NEW ZEALAND
articles.summary: Moon Shadow Expeditions is organizing a 14-day trip to New Zealand next spring to observe Halley's Comet, which offers optimal viewing from the Southern Hemisphere. The expedition will take place in the dark skies of the Mackenzie Basin, featuring expert staff including comet expert Don Machholz and astrophotographer John Gleason, and a range of viewing and photographic equipment. Contact information is provided for those interested in this unique astronomical tour.

articles.title: CLUB 14-INCH DOBSON
articles.summary: Charles Carlson is looking to transfer the club's 14-inch Dobson telescope to another interested member. Members wishing to acquire the telescope should contact him at the provided phone numbers during the day or evening.

articles.title: BOOK LEFT BEHIND
articles.summary: Ron Atwood inadvertently left his "Atlas of Deep Sky Splendors" book on a Honda car belonging to a SJAA member named Rick or Rich at the Glacier Point Star Party. He is very keen to retrieve his book and has provided a contact number for anyone who might have it.

articles.title: SEPTEMBER 7TH SLIDE AND EQUIPMENT NIGHT
articles.summary: SJAA is holding its annual Slide and Equipment Night on September 7th, an event where members display new astronomical equipment, accessories, and astrophotography. The organizer encourages all members to participate and bring items for show and tell, mentioning the possibility of astrophotography prints being available for purchase. The goal is to revive the event's past popularity.

articles.title: A NIGHT AT MIRA OR: HOW TO DEVELOP A SEVERE CASE OF APPARATUS FEVER IN ONE NIGHT BY: CHRIS PRATT
articles.summary: Chris Pratt recounts his exciting night at the Monterey Institute for Research in Astronomy (MIRA), where he and Kevin Medlock observed through the 36-inch telescope. Caretaker Mike Simmons provided a tour, highlighting the observatory's self-sufficiency, before excellent seeing conditions allowed for breathtaking views, particularly of M-51, which left the observers deeply impressed and enthusiastic.
keywords: Monterey Institute for Research in Astronomy

articles.title: THREE SHUTTLE SPARTAN PAYLOADS SCHEDULED FOR 1986
articles.summary: Three Spartan payloads are scheduled for deployment and retrieval by the Space Shuttle in 1986. These include Spartan Halley, an ultraviolet spectrograph for observing Halley's Comet in January, Spartan Xray, an ultraviolet and white light instrument flying in October, and Spartan 3, a stellar spectrographic camera for observing star fields in December.

articles.title: MISSION 51-F (SPACELAB 2) IS DEDICATED TO PHYSICS, ASTRONOMY, AND LIFE SCIENCE
articles.summary: Mission 51-F (Spacelab 2) is dedicated to a broad range of scientific investigations spanning physics, astronomy, and life sciences. Key experiments include studies in solar physics (e.g., SUMER, CHASE, SUSIM), atmospheric and plasma physics (e.g., PDP), high-energy astrophysics, and infrared astronomy. The mission also features mid-deck experiments focused on crew health, plant biology, protein crystal growth, amateur radio, and testing commercial beverage dispensers in microgravity.

articles.title: AN EXCITING YEAR AHEAD FOR ASTRONOMY
articles.summary:
## AN EXCITING YEAR AHEAD FOR ASTRONOMY

Just because of the hype about Halley's, don't forget about the other exciting astronomy missions which will occur over the next year. This September, the Inte...

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE BY: ROBERT FINGERHUT
articles.summary: This space program update reports on the delay of the Spacelab 2 mission, which was aborted on July 12 due to a computer detected problem shortly before liftoff, necessitating the rescheduling of two other flights. Additionally, it announces the successful launch of the European Giotto spacecraft on July 2, destined to intercept Halley's Comet on March 13, 1986, passing within 310 miles.

articles.title: GALAXIES:
articles.summary: This article discusses observations of southern hemisphere galaxies, focusing on those with low declination. It highlights NGC 5128 (Centaurus A), a peculiar radio galaxy, noting its prominent dark dust band even from higher latitudes. The author also describes observing NGC 7213 in Grus, providing detailed instructions for locating this small, round galaxy near Alpha Grus.

articles.title: OPEN CLUSTERS/EMISSION NEBULAE:
articles.summary: This article describes an amateur astronomer's observations of the open cluster NGC 6193 and the adjacent emission nebula NGC 6188 in the constellation Ara from Fiddletown, California in July 1982. The observer noted the double star in NGC 6193 and a faint hazy glow from NGC 6188. The author also invites other Northern California observers to share their experiences with southerly deep-sky objects.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS
articles.summary: This article recounts a less-attended but exceptionally clear star party at Fremont Peak on July 13, where author Jay Reynolds Freeman used 11x80 Celestron binoculars to observe numerous Messier objects, the southern Milky Way, and dark nebulae. The event also featured other amateur astronomers with various telescopes, viewing objects like M-51 and the Veil Nebula, and attempting to find Comet Machholz. Freeman highlights the utility of wide-field binoculars for deep-sky observation and the enjoyment of sharing views with newcomers.

articles.title: COMET RENDEZVOUS/ASTEROID FLYBY RETARGETED
articles.summary: The CRAF (Comet Rendezvous/Asteroid Flyby) mission was retargeted from its original 1987 plan to a March 1991 launch due to budget cuts affecting the Mariner Mark II spacecraft development. The revised mission includes a September 1991 flyby of asteroid Hedwig, followed by a more than two-year rendezvous with Comet Wild 2 beginning in January 1995.

articles.title: VEGA 1 AND 2 ARRIVE AT VENUS
articles.summary: The Russian Vega 1 and 2 spacecraft successfully deployed balloons into Venus' atmosphere, transmitting data for 46 hours at 150,000 feet, and also deployed landers, one of which operated on the surface for 21 minutes, performing chemical analysis and measuring pressure/temperature. These missions utilized various instruments for atmospheric and surface studies. Both spacecraft are now continuing their journey to fly by Halley's Comet in March 1986, carrying additional instruments for comet observation.

articles.title: SHUTTLE MISSION 51-G ALMOST PERFECT
articles.summary: Shuttle Mission 51-G, carried out by the Space Shuttle Discovery from June 17 to June 24, was deemed an "almost perfect" seven-day mission. During its time in orbit, astronauts successfully deployed three communications satellites, tested a laser tracker, and deployed and retrieved a Spartan astrophysics pallet satellite. The mission also carried six Getaway Special canisters.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document is a classifieds section titled "ASTRO ADS," featuring multiple listings for buying and selling astronomical equipment. Individuals are looking to purchase specific telescopes like Dobsonian models, while others are selling a wide range of gear including a Super C8 Plus, a 10-inch f/5 Newtonian tube assembly, various eyepieces, filters, and other accessories.

articles.title: DEEP SKY NOTES - AUGUST BY: STEVE GOTTLIEB
articles.summary: Steve Gottlieb explores the challenges of observing deep sky objects at extreme southern declinations from his location, prompted by the anticipated southern reach of Halley's Comet. He discusses the observational limits imposed by factors like atmospheric conditions and horizon obstructions, noting past successful observations near the southern horizon and wondering if even more southerly objects are detectable.

articles.title: PLANETARY NEBULAE: Just inside the declination band of -40° to -50° is NGC 5132, the "Burst-burst planetary" in Vela. Even at a low elevation it is a striking object in my C8 with a prominent mag 9 central star surrounded by a bright, slightly oval disk. In the 13.1" at 312x I noted a dark region around the central star giving a slightly annular appearance this past February 23 at Digger Pines.
articles.summary: The article details observations of two planetary nebulae: NGC 5132, the 'Burst-burst planetary' in Vela, observed with an 8-inch and 13.1-inch telescope revealing a prominent central star and annular appearance. It also describes a recent observation of IC 2944/2406 in Lupus, noting its brightness and moderate size in a 13-inch telescope during a brief transit at Fremont Peak, though no structural details were evident.

articles.title: GLOBUALRS: Certainly the most famous southern globular cluster is the magnificent Omega Centauri (NGC 5139), located at 13h 27m -47° 29' (2000). At Digger Pines this object can be easily located with the slightest optical aid. At what latitude is this globular a naked-eye object? Generally, the telescopic view is somewhat disappointing to me at this low elevation end this mighty cluster is reduced to a large, fuzzy, ragged snowball with possibly a few bloated stars around the periphery. But last February again was a period of exceptional steadiness, the outer regions were well resolved into numerous stragglers and the large mottled core was plastered with a covering of faint stars. A more certain challenge would be the other two famous southern NGC 5927 in Lupus and NGC 5946 in Norma both at -50° 40' (2000). Has anyone viewed these two from our latitude?
articles.summary: The article focuses on observations of the magnificent southern globular cluster Omega Centauri (NGC 5139), describing its easy location with optical aid from Digger Pines and the author's mixed telescopic experiences, including an exceptionally clear view last February. The author also poses questions regarding Omega Centauri's naked-eye visibility at different latitudes and seeks viewing reports on two other challenging southern globular clusters, NGC 5927 and NGC 5946.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT
articles.summary: This article discusses the dynamic nature of Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS), noting its changing appearance, color, and surrounding features, which vary significantly over time. It includes an observer's report on its current 'golden ochre-yellow' color and the presence of new dark matter east of it. The author also details observational techniques for timing GRS transits, acknowledges the erratic drift motion, and provides revised predictions for its meridian transit times for the upcoming month, advising observers to start looking early due to potential variances.

articles.title: THE 1985 PERSEID METEOR SHOWER BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article details the upcoming 1985 Perseid Meteor Shower, peaking on the morning of August 12th with an expected rate of sixty meteors per hour and minimal lunar interference. It offers photography tips and discusses the unobserved return of Comet Swift-Tuttle, which is responsible for the shower. Additionally, observers are encouraged to look for Halley's Comet (magnitude 13.5) and the mysterious 'Aries Flasher' during the Perseids, with mentions of other minor meteor showers throughout August.

articles.title: PLANETARY NEBULAE IN DELPHINUS, SAGITTA AND VULPECULA
articles.summary: This article discusses the 22 planetary nebulae found within the constellations of Delphinus, Sagitta, and Vulpecula, noting that while M27 is famous, many others are obscure or unobserved visually. It provides guidance for deep-sky observers on how to locate these objects, especially the lesser-known ones, by plotting them on an atlas using provided epoch 2000 coordinates. The author also explains the data presented in an accompanying table, including size, and visual (V) magnitude of the central star, distinguishing between visual and photographic magnitudes.

articles.title: DESCRIPTION OF INDIVIDUAL OBJECTS
articles.summary: This document provides detailed descriptions of various individual planetary nebulae, including their discovery information, photographic and estimated visual magnitudes, surface brightness, and observational challenges. It frequently encourages amateur astronomers to attempt visual observations, often noting if an object has not yet been visually confirmed and suggesting the use of UHC or O-III filters. The article concludes with a comprehensive table listing numerous objects alongside their 2000.0 coordinates, sizes, magnitudes, and brightness values.

articles.title: NGC 6842
articles.summary: This document serves as an observational guide for various planetary nebulae, detailing their discovery, visual characteristics, and observational challenges. It provides practical advice on necessary telescope sizes, magnifications, and recommended filters like UHC and Oxygen-III to view these often dim deep-sky objects. The text covers both well-known objects like M-27 and more elusive targets for amateur astronomers.

articles.title: NGC 6905
articles.summary: The article describes two deep-sky objects, NGC 6905 and A 72. NGC 6905, discovered by John Herschel, is a blue starfield in Delphinus with a visible 14th magnitude center star. A 72, discovered by Abell, is a low surface brightness object requiring UHC or Oxygen filters for observation and has a bright star on its western edge.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article provides an update on several comets, noting the recent discovery of Comet Hartley (1985f) which is brightening and visible in large telescopes. It also mentions Comet Giacobini-Zinner 1984e continues to brighten, while Comet Machholz (1985e) likely did not survive perihelion and has not been re-observed. The author, Don Machholz, shares details about Hartley's discovery and the status of his own namesake comet.

articles.title: DATE R.A. (1950) DEC ELONS MAG.
articles.summary: This document presents a concise tabular ephemeris for a celestial object, detailing its predicted or observed positions and brightness over a period from late July to early September. It lists dates, Right Ascension (1950 epoch), Declination, elongation from the Sun (likely), and estimated apparent magnitude. The data allows for tracking the object's movement and changing visibility in the night sky.

articles.title: Giacobini-Zinner notes
articles.summary: This document provides observational notes and an ephemeris for Comet Giacobini-Zinner, detailing its southward arc trajectory. It highlights close approaches to the Double Cluster on Aug. 10 and NGC 1513 on Aug. 22, and its proximity to Halley's Comet in mid-September. The magnitude estimates are noted as rough, potentially being one magnitude fainter.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND—HALLEY'S COMET
articles.summary: This article discusses Halley's Comet becoming visible to amateur astronomers in August, detailing its increasing brightness and elongation as it approaches the sun and Earth. It provides specific positional data (RA, Dec, Mag) for August, along with observing tips regarding moon phases and how to estimate the comet's coma size. The author also encourages amateur projects and observations.

articles.title: A VISIT TO THE LICK OBSERVATORY BY: MRS. A.A. STOWE
articles.summary: Mrs. A.A. Stowe vividly recounts her journey to the renowned Lick Observatory on Mount Hamilton, near San Jose, California. She describes the scenic, yet challenging, stagecoach drive through the Santa Clara Valley, highlighting the region's natural beauty and the observatory's scientific significance, particularly its 36-inch refractor. The narrative culminates in their arrival, a cordial reception, and a breathtaking sunset viewed from the mountain peak.

articles.title: Observatory Visit Documentation
articles.summary: This document chronicles a visitor's tour of an observatory, led by Professor Perrine. The visit encompassed viewing astronomical transparencies and photographs, exploring a library of historical scientific texts including Galileo's works, and observing Saturn through the facility's prominent telescope. A significant portion of the tour focused on inspecting and understanding various sophisticated scientific instruments such as pluviometers, aerographs, barometers, and seismographs, with detailed explanations provided by Professors Perrine and Schaeberle.

articles.title: The Lick Observatory Article
articles.summary: This article provides an overview of Lick Observatory, detailing its sophisticated time-keeping instruments and the imminent arrival of the Crossley reflector, a significant gift. It highlights the observatory's top-tier instrumental equipment but laments its inadequate income. The piece also describes the scenic beauty of the observatory's mountain location, recounts a historical anecdote about benefactor James Lick, and outlines visitor policies.

articles.title: TELESCOPE SALE!!!
articles.summary: The Fremont Peak Observatory Association is holding a fund-raising telescope sale at Fremont Peak State Park on Saturday, August 10th, 1985, at 2:00 PM. The sale offers significantly discounted Celestron demonstrator and factory-return telescopes, mounts, and tripods, with all proceeds dedicated to funding the construction of a 30" Observatory. Items are sold first-come, first-served, with staff available to assist buyers with setup and use.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: The article details the monthly general meetings of the SJAA, which are held at 8 PM at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, located at 18011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd in Los Gatos, California. This venue also hosts the SJAA's "Indoor Star Party," and the document provides specific driving directions to the location.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: Grant Ranch County Park is a popular observing site for the SJAA, located on Mt. Hamilton Road. The article provides detailed driving directions to the park entrance and critical information regarding access, including a combination lock (4565) for the front gate after sunset, emphasizing the need to relock it. It also mentions an alternative observing area further up Mt. Hamilton Road within the park.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to Henry Coe State Park, advising travelers to take Hwy 101 south, exit East Dunne, and continue for about 12 miles past Anderson Reservoir. It includes specific parking instructions near a locked gate, providing a club combination for access, and offers guidance for arriving after dark, emphasizing the use of parking lights only.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, a designated observing site, specifically mentioning Coulter Camp as the setup location for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It emphasizes the use of parking lights only after dark at the park. The article is published by the San Jose Astronomical Association.

articles.title: OFFICERS:
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers of an organization, detailing the President, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer. For each officer, it provides their name, title, physical address, and phone number, serving as a contact directory for the organization's leadership.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
articles.summary: This document lists the current members of the Board of Directors, providing each individual's name and contact phone number. It serves as a directory for reaching the board members.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS EDITOR:
articles.summary: This document introduces an "Ephemeris Editor," which is likely a software tool designed for managing or creating astronomical ephemerides. The contact information for its creator, John P. Gleason, is provided.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details different membership tiers, including standard, junior (under 18), and an option for a Sky & Telescope magazine subscription, along with their respective fees. The form provides fields for applicant information and instructions for submission via mail or in person at an SJAA meeting.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document presents an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about the astronomical interests, telescope ownership, and areas of expertise of individuals. It aims to understand the preferences and potential contributions of members or participants within an astronomical community.
